member.name: T:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.ChainOfCommand

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.ExpressionTree.CleanUpTreeStructure
member.summary: Cleans up the tree structure to ensure that all Connective Nodes have both children assigned. If a Connective has no children assigned, it will be removed. If a Connective has one child assigned, it will be removed and child moved in its place.

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode.GetPrecedence
member.summary: Node with lower precedence is evaluated first

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode.InsertLeft(SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode)
member.summary: Inserts specified node as a Left child of this node. Steps will be taken to ensure tree correctness after this operation.

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode.InsertRight(SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode)
member.summary: Inserts specified node as a Right child of this node. Steps will be taken to ensure tree correctness after this operation.

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode.InjectInto(SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode,System.Func{SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IPredicateConnectiveNode})
member.summary: Injects this node into tree hierarchy of specified node.

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode.ReplaceChildNode(SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode,SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode)
member.summary: Replaces old child node with a new child node. Steps will be taken to ensure tree correctness after this operation. Old node will be completely removed from the tree.

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode.AssignParent(SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode)
member.summary: Assigns a new Parent (or null) to this Node. No further action will be taken to ensure tree correctness.

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode.ClearChildAssignment(SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode,SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.ChildNodePosition@)
member.summary: Removes the specified child from this node. Autmatically determines if child is a Left or Right node. No further action will be taken to ensure tree correctenss.

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode.GetChildPosition(SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode)
member.summary: Returns the position (Left or Right) of a child in this node.

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode.AssignChild(SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.IExpressionTreeNode,SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Collections.Trees.ChildNodePosition)
member.summary: Assigns the node to Left or Right child position slot. No further action will be taken to ensure tree correctness.

member.param: Target Node which will be replaced by Source, and joined with source's new sub-tree

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.DateTimeContext.#ctor(System.Func{System.DateTime})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. Current time can be calculated in a function. For example, to 'move seven days back in time' we can call: new DateTimeContext(() => return DateTime.Now.Subtract(TimeSpan.FromDays(7)));

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DateTimeExtensions.ToInvariantDateString(System.DateTime)
member.summary:
DateTime.ToString("dd/MM/yyyy") will return date in different format depending on current culture: EN: 23/11/2011 DE: 23.11.2011 CN: 23-11-2011
This method will automatically use invariant culture to return date in format of dd/MM/yyyy i.e. not replacing '/' with a culture specific seprator

member.name: T:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions
member.summary: Extensions of a Double type.

member.name: F:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions.DefaultPrecision
member.summary: Default precision used when comparing two double numbers. It is a very small (the smallest possible) number for which 1.0 + DefaultPrecision != 1.0 The distance from 1.0 to the next largest double-precision number, that is eps = 2^(-52). Double Mantissa is 52 bits long. http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/System.Double(v=vs.110).aspx

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions.AreClose(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Checks if two double precision numbers are equal given the precision of [DoubleExtensions.DefaultPrecision] For example: 0.01 != 0.1 * 0.1 due to floating point accuracy problems [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point#Accuracy_problems] (0.1 * 0.1 == 0.010000000000000002)

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions.AreClose(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Checks if two double precision numbers are equal given some precision. For example: 0.01 != 0.1 * 0.1 due to floating point accuracy problems [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point#Accuracy_problems] (0.1 * 0.1 == 0.010000000000000002)

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions.IsCloseTo(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Checks if double precision number is equal to another double precision number given the precision of [DoubleExtensions.DefaultPrecision]. For example: 0.01 != 0.1 * 0.1 due to floating point accuracy problems [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point#Accuracy_problems] (0.1 * 0.1 == 0.010000000000000002)

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions.IsCloseTo(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Checks if double precision number is equal to another double precision number given some precision. For example: 0.01 != 0.1 * 0.1 due to floating point accuracy problems [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point#Accuracy_problems] (0.1 * 0.1 == 0.010000000000000002)

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions.IsLessThan(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Checks if double precision number is less than another double precision number given the precision of [DoubleExtensions.DefaultPrecision]. For example: 0.01 != 0.1 * 0.1 due to floating point accuracy problems [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point#Accuracy_problems] (0.1 * 0.1 == 0.010000000000000002)

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions.IsLessThan(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Checks if double precision number is less than another double precision number given some precision. For example: 0.01 != 0.1 * 0.1 due to floating point accuracy problems [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point#Accuracy_problems] (0.1 * 0.1 == 0.010000000000000002)

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions.IsGreaterThan(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Checks if double precision number is greater than another double precision number given the precision of [DoubleExtensions.DefaultPrecision]. For example: 0.01 != 0.1 * 0.1 due to floating point accuracy problems [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point#Accuracy_problems] (0.1 * 0.1 == 0.010000000000000002)

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions.IsGreaterThan(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Checks if double precision number is greater than another double precision number given some precision. For example: 0.01 != 0.1 * 0.1 due to floating point accuracy problems [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point#Accuracy_problems] (0.1 * 0.1 == 0.010000000000000002)

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions.IsLessThanOrClose(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Checks if double precision number is less than or equal to another double precision number given the precision of [DoubleExtensions.DefaultPrecision]. For example: 0.01 != 0.1 * 0.1 due to floating point accuracy problems [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point#Accuracy_problems] (0.1 * 0.1 == 0.010000000000000002)

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions.IsLessThanOrClose(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Checks if double precision number is less than or equal to another double precision number given some precision. For example: 0.01 != 0.1 * 0.1 due to floating point accuracy problems [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point#Accuracy_problems] (0.1 * 0.1 == 0.010000000000000002)

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions.IsGreaterThanOrClose(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Checks if double precision number is greater than or equal to another double precision number given the precision of [DoubleExtensions.DefaultPrecision]. For example: 0.01 != 0.1 * 0.1 due to floating point accuracy problems [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point#Accuracy_problems] (0.1 * 0.1 == 0.010000000000000002)

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.DoubleExtensions.IsGreaterThanOrClose(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Checks if double precision number is greater than or equal to another double precision number given some precision. For example: 0.01 != 0.1 * 0.1 due to floating point accuracy problems [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_point#Accuracy_problems] (0.1 * 0.1 == 0.010000000000000002)

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.StringExtensions.GetLengthWithExpandedTabs(System.String,System.UInt16)
member.summary: Returns length of the string with expanded tabs (if tabs were replaced with spaces ' '); For example, assuming default tabSize == 4, "a\t" = 4 "aa\t" = 4 "aaa\t" = 4 "aaaa\t" = 8 "\ta" = 5 "\ta\t" = 8

member.name: M:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.Extensions.StringExtensions.ExpandTabs(System.String,System.UInt16)
member.summary: Exapnds tabs replacing them with spaces. For example, assuming default tabSize == 4, "a\t" => "a " "aa\t" => "aa " "aaa\t" => "aaa " "aaaa\t" => "aaaa " "\ta" => " a" "\ta\t" => " a "

member.name: T:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.TreeTraversalMode
member.summary: Tree traversal mode (Breadth First, Depth First, Bottom Up)

member.name: F:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.TreeTraversalMode.BreadthFirst
member.summary: Start at root and explore all neightboring nodes, then explore each neightbor node in turn folowing same rule (neightboring nodes first)

member.name: F:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.TreeTraversalMode.DepthFirst
member.summary: Start at root and explore as far as possible along each branch before backgracking.

member.name: F:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.TreeTraversalMode.BottomUp
member.summary: Start at the leaf nodes and explore by moving up the tree

member.name: F:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.TreeTraversalMode.Default
member.summary: Breadth First is the Default

member.name: T:SquaredInfinity.Foundation.WeakEventHandler`4
member.summary:
Provides a layer between Event Subscriber and Event Provider. Normally using EventProvider.Event += EventSubscriber.EventHandler; would create a strong reference from EventProvider to EventSubscriber. This strong reference would prevent EventSubscriber from Garbage Collection.
WeakEventHandler holds a Weak-Reference to EventSubscriber allowing it to be Garbage Collected when needed.
